												This game is pretty much dead in the water. I played this game in it's first few years, 2007-2010, and it was great.. 												I played Fiesta sometime in 2010-2011 so I'm not new to this game, was on and off the game for about a year before I quit for good. This is going to be a fair review for a game that is quite old compared to the "new-gen" mmo's, comparing the good parts and the bad. Now the only reason I recommend this game is because I would recommend it to new players who are playing their first mmo, why you ask? Because this game is fairly good when one doesn't expect anything from a mmo, people that have played mmo's before are not going to like it only because they have played better. Fiesta isn't top notch and never will be but it's a good starting point for anyone who really wants to start getting into online gaming. Fiesta has a nice community, diverse classes (traditional mage/fighter/cleric/archer type of deal with a few different ones, crusader/trickster), and a huge PvE aspect from level 1-115 (Or whatever the cap is at now). When I say PvE I mean there's a lot of things to do, but there's a short list of what you SHOULD do to level and not just mess around. You can get pretty much anything without paying a penny but its extremely difficult, there's only 2 people that I know of that have never payed a penny and still were able to cap with high end gears. The guild/academy system is very useful as you can always find help provided that you joined popular guild or a guild with at least 5 people who still play. Now for the people that have played mmo's before, don't bother trying with this game. Compared to most mmo's this is pretty far down the list of "good games." It's pretty old and follows old mmo standard playstyles, it's very grindy and it's very P2W (pay to win) there's a large gap when you compare people who don't pay vs those who do. And it's not spend 10$ and you can get some good stuff like in other games, you nearly have to pay 40-50$ a month now to be properly "geared" with sc (slime cash/cashshop) items for the MONTH. Now the PvP is very tricky. I can say that it's bad and that it doesn't require any skill for a fighter/mage since they're the "PvP classes" of the game since they're easiest to spam skills with or that the cash shop really overly unbalances the PvP with the stat increases + some multipliers of skills = insta death but I have seen people fight really well using any other character that is supposively "bad" for PvP so it really does depend on skill in the end along with a little push of SC. ( the company has got to make money somehow right?)In the end, recommended as someone's first mmo but not recommended for anyone who has played any mmo before.

												If you're an old player returning to fiesta out of nostalgia, keep in mind that its not the same game anymore. Leveling isnt as hard as it used to be, and quests feel rushed. It feels like rather than increasing the exp rate of the game, Gamigo decided to add more, seemingly meaningless quests which give ridiculous amounts of exp. You can accept and turn in quests without even being near the NPC you got it from. This does mean that the "pay to level" system of the older outspark game is gone, but it doesnt feel as satisfying to level (I hit level 60 in 3 days, whereas it used to be a huge achievement). The Trickster felt like Outsparks final attempt to reinvigorate the game before they turned it over to gamigo. And gamigo responded by adding the Crusader, a class which seems so rushed that it doesnt even exist below level 60, and it even has some skills copy pasted from other classes.I can see that Gamigo are really trying to update and reinvent the game, with graphics updates, new quests, and a quicker leveling system, which allows you to get into the action faster. It even merged all the servers into a couple of servers to make the servers full of people again. As a result, this isnt the same game as it used to be, but its an evolving, fun game nonetheless.Ultimately, this isnt the golden '105 cap' fiesta that I remember, but I'm not gonna say it isn't worth playing. While its not the game I poured endless hours of my childhood into, its still a good game. Fiesta used to be hailed as a "pay to win" game, but now more than ever I feel that this isnt true. You can do really well without paying a cent. Im going to miss the days of stacking, endless grinding and massive guild raids on Karen, but the game is still fun. If you're coming to revive an old interest, you may be better off on a private server. But if you're willing to try a new game, this will be good.

												This is the game that got me into online gaming. What can I say? I saw an ad, liked the colorful characters, and signed up. It's a fairly unimaginative game with very little free customization. I began playing back in 2008 and when I tried signing in a few months ago, my characters had been deleted, including all my mounts, custom character designs, and upgraded weapons (all of which cost money). I didn't try very hard to get the game back up and working after that.But back in 2008, I invested a ton of time and a nice chunk of money in Fiesta Online. What eventually drove me away was the community and the grinding. If either could have been better, I might have stuck around but the carpal tunnel-like symptoms and the bickering were enough to make me quit.I tried signing in again today, knowing full well it would mean starting over. I was curious. The same three hairstyles, three faces, and three hair colors are present. They updated the character creation screen but it fails to impress. They added a class, which I've only played for a brief period of time, but the mechanics of the game are still pretty much the same. The starting gear is the same cowgirl-esque stuff from 2008. They added a tutorial which I find frustrating to get through but maybe that's because I've done this all before. I think it could have been a bit more streamlined than it presently is. It was really boring standing in place as I swing the same mallet from 2008 at the same Honeying for several minutes before it dies.As a Cleric, I still don't get any offensive abilites until a handful of levels in. The graphics are the same. Roumen appears to be the same. The controls are still clunky and because I've experienced other games since Fiesta, it was enough to make me lose interest. When I closed the game down, the same "Fiesta.bin has stopped working" error came up. Ah, nostalgia.It's a very grind-heavy game in which dying means redoing HOURS of repetitive monster killing. Some levels give you a small handful of quests, others give you none meaning you have to space your quest turn-ins out so you don't go crazy.All in all, the game does not appear to be any better than it was 6 years ago but I can't say I was expecting it to be.I will, however, say that I rather liked the Kingdom Quests and still think they're a neat idea. You sign up for a KQ and go into an instanced zone with a number of other players and defeat the end boss. I would say the KQs are probably the more creative aspect of Fiesta Online. They're timed and utilize different mechanics to make them interesting. They tend to require a decent amount of teammwork which can be both good and bad. I also like that, even though I'm currently back on foot and moving slowly, I can press a button to lead me to my objective and basically AFK until I get there.

												So, I have to take the time out to give this game a review. Despite the number of hours logged through Steam, I have played this game for a very long time. It deserves some love. Let me tell you a little about Fiesta Online.If you're looking for the next-big-thing, this isn't it. No, it's not like WoW or TERA. It's not Black Desert, either. It's an older game that's changed companies a few times, had it's share of population dips, and (shock) still has some bugs. It IS, however, still a very good game and will provide you with a lot of old-fashioned entertainment. I'm not going to do a formal Pros/Cons, but I am going to casually tell you about the game should you be in the midst of a decision on whether or not you want to try it out. This game is very generic in a lot of good ways. Yep, you read that right. It has all of the traditional things you would want in a MMO. Yes, you can buy and level up skills. Yeah, you can quest to your heart's content. It's got the trinity system you'd want from a standard game like this. The game still gets new content. It still gets patches that work on improving existing problems. The graphics have even been updated recently. It has six classes with each having a branch-choice at level 100 for a total of 12 end-game roles. The game has just the right amount of tradtion to relax ya. Grab a cold drink, sit  back, and enjoy some good old-fashioned game play.Aesthetically speaking, the maps are bright, colorful, and easy on the eyes. There's not a huge deal of customization, but you do have the option of furthering your character's design through the cash shop. Speaking of, I've always leveled just fine without using the Cash Shop. (That pay-to-win crap is, well, crap). If you're looking for a good ole anime game, then this is it! (However, I would like to throw out there that I've always found it odd that your characters can only be light-skinned. Then again, they don't have natural hair colors much either). Perhaps the most enjoyable, and unique, aspect of the game is the "Kingdom Quest" system. It's an instance-based raid, but it doesn't depend on your class. So, no, dear DPS players, you're not going to wait an hour in que. It's not a perfect system, but it's different, fun, and is currently working very well. When the game changed companies awhile back, the population dropped a bit. This made the Kingdom Quest system kind of broken. I mean, it's hard to run an instance with no people in it. They cared enough to finally merge the servers, and they're working great now. If all else fails, you do have the traditional instances where you find your own party members.The game isn't easy to level. It plays like a casual game, but it actually has some pretty thought-provoking challenges in it. While it's not as hard as it used to be, you're not going to cap in a month. It takes time, effort, and by the time you're there, it feels fantastic! Not to mention, the game has new bosses and raids for end-game. I'm looking forward to them!So, no, Fiesta isn't the best game in the world, but it WILL be fun for you to play should you decide to stick with it. I hope you decide to give the game a go and make tons of new friends in the end!Best of luck,xDYimy

												WARNING: THIS WILL FEEL MORE LIKE A COMPLAINT THAN A REVIEWOkay, I'll stop being lazy and post an actual review of this game. For the heads up so you don't go all, "You haven't even tried this game!" on me, I have played this game from 2009-2013 (with several breaks inbetween).Anyway, this game is the generic anime MMORPG with men running around disguised as women and vice-versa (you know, to keep the creeps away). With a click-and-sit system and months of grinding-even with an EXP. buff. Honestly, all I can say is the friends/guildmates I met are the ones that kept me coming back after 2009-2010.PS. (11/1/14) After looking at this half-done "review", I take back my statement with men-playing-as-women. Some men just enjoy trying different things, same goes with women.PROBLEMS WITH THIS GAME?The cash shop. 'Nuff said.The problem with the cash shop, is that it ruins PvP. Entirely. I remember walking into Uruga (main city), fresh 60, with a bunch of 100's and 90's with an arrow above their head (which I later learned, it was a debuff), and I thought it was the coolest thing ever. However, PvP since then has died down - rapidly. The excitement of Abyss wars, FBZ wars, or just wars in general, used to be the most exciting and anticipating thing in the game that kept me going (well, part of it was my guildmates).The cash shop allows you to use CHARMS IN PVP.When you kill someone, "CHARMED!"When someone kills you, "CHARMED!"When you get killed by the hammer in PvP KQ, "CHARMED11!!1"Nobody assumes a player is good anymore - heck, the "good" players are considered good when they use charms. However, I am not discrediting those who worked hard in raids to earn their well-earned gear. Just those who assume one is using charms or is one of those pvp-charm-users.(A/N) This is an exaggeration, of course. However, some people really did act like this. Also, charms aren't as bad as they seem, it's just that it caused people to become somewhat paranoid of it and believe that everyone that doesn't take 10k dmg from them is charmed.Right, now for the more serious problem. PvE.This game is literally a grind-fest. At level 90 (or so), I was able to run Leviathan runs for gear and EXP. While using an EXP. booster, it still took me OVER 4-6 HOURS just to gain maybe 20-40%. That's terrible. Kid me not, it was MUCH longer once I hit 100. (I don't even understand why I stuck around). Heck, I was looking forward to leveling my alts again, which normally would be the thing I hated the most.(11/1/14)At level 93 or 94, all you can really do - besides that terrible leviathan run - was to do a quest repeat which gave 1% every turn in and had terrible drop rates.Leviathan became around 10-15% every 4-6 hour grind in the later 90's.I salute everyone who took the time to level their characters to 100+.PS. I hated when they stopped making that cool mage animation with their spammable skill.. forgot which, but they kicked and it was cool.GOOD THINGS?Okay, yes, this game had a few good things. (From my point of view, it was the nostalgia that kept me going). If you're lucky, you would've made a guild/found a guild that's friendly and fun to be with, making everything much more worth it. However, the rest of the community... not so much.Although they rarely do, but the events in this game are fantastic. My favorite was the Christmas one and I kept killing GM's. :)The flashiness of the weapons - yesss. I thought +10'ing my stuff made my character look absolutely beast. Heck, when I first hit 100, I walked around (like a boss) Elderine and Roumen with my +10's looking so fresh. (Then in a few seconds, I would be bombarded by, "Buffplz," but who cares?)RIGHT. I WILL NOW BE GETTING DOWNVOTES, BECAUSE.... this didn't really feel like an actual review, more like an experience of my pain. Haha.TL;DR. I would never play this game again and would not recommend it - unless you like big grinds and people walking around in the opposite gender's character. ;)PS. THAT MOUNT DURATION STUFF WAS ABSOLUTELY MONEY-EATING.PPS. I downloaded this game on steam and sat there for 20 minutes, just to write a review.

												A F2P PLAYER'S REVIEW!Well nearly 2k hours into fiesta and still haven't decided to write something about it I figured I'd write one now, anyway, your probably wondering why I'm not recommending this game. Clearly 1.8k hours I SHOULD know something about fiesta and how it works. Well your in luck as I do, bare bones this game is extremely P2W and grindy as **** to the point that it just became to much. Now in some more detail about this game:Lets start with the bad parts of the game!-The cash shop:       Most MMORPGs usually have a cash shop which you buy stuff from and for me personally any cash shop that offers boosts to a player's stats things such as DMG,crit, crit rate, HP or whatever form of boost aren't exactly something I like unless it's from a event or obtainable via in game boss or dungeon run things of that nature that can give F2P players the same opportunities as P2W players and I do understand that companies must be profitable to maintain operations of a game however fiesta I feel just lets you download the game for free just to make a few hundreds or more off of you and make you work your *** off for close to nothing. Not only that but their cast shot is virtually stat boost that only last for 30 days at a time before you have to buy something to replace your old outfit.What's also kind of funny the cash shop can make a mage into a tank.-The community:Now this one is a little hard to put on the bad however there are a lot more bad apples then there is good ones when I first started playing this game I joined a guild abid it was a small guild with a good guild leader and members and they REALLY were the only people that kept me playing for as long as I did, however, a more big guild eventually absorbed our guild into it and I met a much larger community and that's when I realized how bad the community really is most of the level 100+ abid some aren't as bad as others but still it's bad most people I met seemed to be WAYY to power hungry and into PvP (Which is really broken due to the nature of the game) ill admit that being power hungry isn't a bad thing or being into PvP, however, one instance from the guild I was in one of the strongest players (We had 2-3 of the top players in our server) in our guild decided that instead of sharing loot which was distributed by how many runs you do which normally take about 2-3 hours to get done per run to keep the loot they got that did get our guild leader angry but decided to let them keep the loot because of the fear of losing one of our top players rather then keeping his word and promises to the other within our guild.For as long as I've been with this game I did noticed that newer player areas really don't have any life to it normally you wont see other players in Roumen (Newb town) or they'll be afk or something like that. Most people that are lower levels get power leveled by higher level players normally for free or they'll ask for gold in return for leveling (yes it's not against the TOS at least the power leveling part is not so much the asking for money part).-Events... This one is pretty short, Events in this game are practically nothing. Most events are done on forums which I can say just is lame because it gives the game a feel of nothing interesting is happening which is most part nothing IS happening. And when a event is out it's normally just something for Halloween or xmas that's really the only 2 events you are normally guaranteed to have. Most other events happen on blue moons or out of the blue.-The player marketAnother short one I'm getting tired of writing so ill try to keep everything from here on out short. The player market everything is really over priced even after I quit the prices of things only really just gone up and that's about it. It's a real problem.-ScammersNot that often you'll find people that would go out of their way to screw you over for money or whatever but a common scam in this game is gifting this game does let you gift cash shop items from other players sweet and all right? Wrong, as people normally know you need to spend money to be able to even gift (I don't know much about it as I never gifted or brought items from the cash shop) Scammers know this and would say something like give me the money first and ill gift you first or if they want to get something for free from a gifter they'll asked to be gifted first. There are other scams out there, however, that's the most common one other scams aren't done as much however that's the most common one out there.-THE GRINDOH GOD, Can I say this game becomes just to grindy to the point you have to do it for hours to just see 5% for level 105 at black bear repeat quest with a party of level 100-105 this game starts to get grindy at levels 61+ and slows and slows down a lot to the point it's not fun to play even with a group of high level players the grind becomes old pretty quick.The good of this game FINALLY!So here we are at the good things about fiesta good on you if you read this far into it.-The communityWhile this is in the bad part it also has it's good bits it really does if your able to find a guild or a group of players to play with regularly this game becomes VERYYY addictive because of how fun it can be to run a high level kingdom quest or do group repeat quests to level up.-It's about as classic of a MMORPG as you can getTitle says it all fiesta is for the most part the most classic of a MMORPG as you can get to at least as far as I know.                                           -The end-I know this review isn't a perfect one at all but I do hope it help you out a fair bit in not picking this game up.  my personal rating of this game it would have to be 3.3 out of 10.*I don't intend to rework this review anytime soon nor will I probably play this game again as it is WAY to p2w.

With regards to Fieta Online's cash shop, I find the convienence items pretty expensive for the average person, thus not really aquirable enough to call them game breaking.  If the cash shop was truly game breaking, the game would have shut down years ago.  Give Fiesta Online a shot.  There are far worse MMORPG experiences out there and even more games that are just cash grab fads.  Fiesta Online has survived throughout the years.  That alone should say something about the quality of the game.

												Fiesta Online is a free-to-play MMORPG. Fairly standard stuff. The cartoonish graphics are easy on the eyes and the Lore is fairly rich. Most importantly, however, the community is fairly nice and it's easy to make friends here. While there are items that require cash to buy, there's no real pressure in the game to get them. If I were to recommend any MMORPG to someone, it would definitely be this one.However, Fiesta Online has one critical flaw: it is a time-draining, virtually-endless game. Do not play this game unless you are willing to sacrifice at least 4 hours a day, every day, for the rest of your life. The game is definitely easy to work with for the first ten levels, but the next ten are truly horrifying. Getting to level 20 in this game is incredibly difficult. It's not that the game is challenging; the hard part comes from forcing yourself to sit there and grind for the countless hours necessary to get out of the gloom that is the lv. 17-19 range. The game picks up after that, but only for so long. The cruel cycle continues to repeat itself. This game will eat your life.If you like the typical WoW-style MMORPG setup, then, sure, this game is great. However, ultimately, I cannot in good conscience recommend this game to anyone.

												Slight disappointment...Fiesta is a Free to Play "Anime" MMORPG, Anime being a loose term for the style of art used and not the actual feel of the gameplay itself.Graphics:  5/10The Graphic team that put this together probably put alot of effort into it, but the cocders who turned it into a game probably stripped away alot of what they did to make room for other functions... They should have put alot more into the visualstyle instead of leaving things bare-bones pastels. Not bad, but definitely not good... evenf or a Free-to-Play game.Audio:  3/10Like most MMORPGs the audio ranges of the game almost feel like they are bringing back the old 8-bit music ranges. Constant loops and single grunt dubs are all you have to look forward to. This combined with some other lack luster features convinced me to do an uninstall after reacching level 7.GamePlay: 1.5/10Like most other MOORPGs out there the variety of quests are limited to:1) Kill this for me2) Get this for me3) Do this for "Yourself"Nothing really new here, but they way that the quests were set up could have been more creative without hacing to add any new features. Grinding gets boring fast, and having to use the rest function (which heals you at an agonizingly slow rate) shows you that you either have to be as patient as a Saint, or be willing to forrk over some cash for a game that isn't going to be getting much better.For the most part, this game was everything I hope to not find in an MMORPg of any caliber, but one thing that did please me was the "Free Stat" system which most RPG players are happy to see. The ability to choose where your stat point go into is always a nice thing :3So unless you have the patience to lug through a fairly clumsy battle system and agonizingly slow walking speed, you might want to look into play some other MMORPG. You've been warned.

												Where to start. Firstly I guess all in all, if you have an addictive personality, love to spend money, love to be the best there is after a very short amount of time, then this is your type of game. Now if you want to want to know what makes Fiesta the worst MMO around, continue browsing. It needs to be noted down that this is in no way a free-to-play game, despite what some advertisements may suggest. This is by far, the epitomy of not just micro-transactions, but pay-to-win or uninstall before your account goes dry. With that being said, you can spend on average $50 a month alone just on costumes, accessaries, cosmetics, useful power-ups such as extenders/charms etc, and that's not including the amount you need to actually get good gears, enhance them, have in-game money for pots/stones/scrolls, and then include the amount of money you'll end up spending on trying to get a skin for your shield or weapon to look and be as strong as everyone else. But the strongest players, myself included at one point, were spending over $200-300 a month just on one game to keep up appearances, raid daily, PvP daily, and continuously get better gears. Most of the systems involved in-game are currently broken, including levelling, enhancing gears/weapons, farming for gears/weapons, and the community itself is just as appalling. It took a slow tumble from 2010 and onwards, down further to what most people could refer to as, ELO Hell in League. Spammers, scammers, ♥♥♥♥♥ and prats are loose from everyone to converse with, and the amount of times a person can get catfished in one game alone, well this would definitely be situated for the award ceremonies. As most people have stated, the game used to be good, had a very friendly and on-going community, it still had it's problems, especially at higher levels within specific guilds, but hey, what game doesn't.

												I have played this game a lot. i currently have 192 hours mostly on my archer level 76. This game has really good combat in my opinion because the skills and healing with sp/mana hp/sp pots and stones is really fun and different from most games of the genre. It has a really good core idea with lots of little funny and odd anime stories but i have more complaints then things I like.       I said that I really like the combat which in a very grindy game is a must need. You dont have a million abilities but you have enough to keep you interested. I like that the balance is really good because there are a lot of buffs you can do to your character. You more often then not will have scrolls or potions on that increase your stats tiers 1-5 that can all be created through crafting and receiving from quests. The stat system is very normal and well made. The game has lots of different cool thins like your mini house. You reviece a mini house that over time restores your hp and sp over time from sitting in this mushroom that you can change the look of the higher levels you reach. Now on to the bad things.       This game has a decent structure I think with a few personal things gamigo has come up with with cool buff systems and healing items to keep you in battle. But there are a few things that make this game absolutely atrocious at times. I am not sure what level it starts happening at (around level 50 I think) when you die you loose hard earned xp. Ok this seems ok sure you die and you loose like 5% of your base xp FINE. But this game was made so that when you level up you get a certain amount of quests for the next level and if you die to many times durring that level you are suck having to grind or do "repeat quests" which are quests that give next to no xp which are very grindy and take forever to do just so you can get the last 10% of your xp bar to level up and get a new set of quests to go grind more mobs. They try to cover up the flaw by giving you the "repeat quests". Another thing is the economy... THERE IS NO SUCH THING because the way you can sell items to other players is by setting up a mini house and selling your items in a stationary spot which means if you wanna sell things you have to be online. And instead of playing while your online which the makes should be emphasizing you sometimes just have to get on and go afk all day to make money.        If gamigo would just let as keep our xp when we die and come up with an auction house or somethign like world of warcraft then you would be afloat i think.

												I have sunk a few years into this game. I originally had it before it came out on Steam, and the only reason I got it through steam was because I stopped playing and uninstalled it at one point. It was originally owned by a company called Outspark, and it hasn't changed all that much since it switched over to Gamigo. Mostly skin changes for monsters and the starter town.. oh and maybe some NPCs. In terms of classes, it doesnt really matter what you pick since all the quests are the same. There is no story line whatsoever. There are seasonal events, and the premium item store holds some goodies if you are willing to spend real cash in order to get store currency. It has been said that FO has become a pay to win game, but as long as you're willing to put in the hours, it is possible to reach cap without premium items. I dont suggest battlefields, pvp dungeons or PVP kingdom quests without premium items... which I guess proves the pay to win section.The enhancement system is also a lot harder if you dont use premium items, and even though enhancement offers some perks, and makes your gear prettier... it is still possible to play without, or you can always farm/sell for in game currency and hope to buy off another player. Players stores can be ridiculously priced though.. unfortunately people dont really offer an item for what it's really worth and tend to overprice useless gear. Be mindful of your class and stats before buying from other players, and really consider whether it is actually worth the price.It has its pros and cons like any game, but if you're into things like this then by all means give it a go. It's not so bad, as long as you're willing to sink hours into it. (Though... if memory serves... since I havent started a new character in a very long time... you can get to level 30 within a couple hours)

												I've played Fiesta for a few years now, and I just want to clarify some things up.Fiesta has changed drastically over the years since I've joined the community, and I'm pretty well adjusted to it. It is not a pay to win game, it is only pay to win if you choose to pay to win. The only useful things you can buy that actually help combat wise and gameplay is enhancement bundles, so your item doesn't break when you want to upgrade it. Fashion gives you slight crit buffs or hp etc. and it's not that effective unless you have a lot, either way you don't need to pay to get these kinds of buffs. Just build your character right, and you have a pretty easy going time.[Fighters] usually build END, and STR. Me personally, I build STR and DEX for damage and so I don't miss and have much more evasion when I fight.[Archers] build DEX, SPR, and sometimes END depending on what kind of gameplay you would like, like if you wanted to AoE, you would need a bit more END.[Clerics] build full END, or END, SPR, and STR (sometimes). Clerics are the tankiest class in the game, but you also build SPR for more mana so you don't just kill it with a set of buffs.[Mages] build INT and SPR. INT for magic damage (I usually go full INT), and SPR for more mana and crits.[Tricksters] build STR, SPR, and DEX. Tricksters have the fastest attack speed and the highest crit chance, evasion, and hit chance. I mained a trickster for a while before switching to Fighter.[Crusaders] I have yet to experience. I'm sure they build STR and END. I've seen some crusaders that build tanky and others that build pure damage and destroy everything. Though you need a level 60+ character in order to make a Crusader.But yeah in conclusion, I would give this game a try. It's pretty fun, just takes some time to get used to some stuff. There are even vaults you get every so levels that help your experience, whether it be from fashion to mounts, from resting houses to weapons. They reward you for leveling up. Plus if you're running out of money, you could join an academy and every level from 10-60, you'll get money and item rewards for leveling up. I'd give it a try.

												Summary: Fiesta is an anime-themed massively multiplayer online (MMO) game that emphasizes group play. It is simple enough for ten-year-olds, but a few annoying bugs and a very grindy lategame may discourage you after many hours of play. It is free, and buying in-game items can help speed you along without breaking the game.Positives:1. Fiesta is simple as MMOs go: you don't so much *win* the game, but you gain levels by earning EXP from completing quests. Quests mostly require killing monsters, collecting drops from monsters, or gathering items in the wilderness. The quests and overarching storyline are text-based and perhaps tangential to the game itself; there is virtually no real "roleplaying" of your character. Don't let the anime feel fool you: you spend the bulk of your active gaming time looking for monster spawn points and exterminating them.2. If dressing up your character in funny and cute cosmetic items is a draw for you, you will be pleasantly surprised at the wide variety of available costumes, hats, ears, pets, and mounts you can (rarely) earn or buy in the real-money store. Most cosmetics give a mild buff, such as increased critical hits or more EXP, and some can be earned by leveling, playing games of chance in the Lucky House, or completing timed rewards during in-game events.  You can run around in a t-shirt, butterfly wings and rainbow tube socks while fighting the bad guys, and still have all your gear equipped and active. Even a free-to-player can earn about 15 specific cosmetics by the time a character reaches level 66.3. A handful of typical classes provides some variety, but you only acquire perhaps 10-20 skills unique to each class, so there isn't the deep customization you would find in action RPGs like Diablo or World of Warcraft. That said, you can spend skill points on your favorite skills to make them more powerful, cheaper to cast, or to refresh their cooldowns faster. You also get stat points to increase the raw abilities of your character also.4. Fiesta boasts one one of the few truly female-friendly gaming communities. Also, the gender of your character can be chosen on creation regardless of class and without effect on your character's stats. Also, if you're a parent of a potential user, Fiesta has virtually no content that is inappropriate for preteens; only the chatter of the other players need be monitored. There is also no way in-game to purchase real-money content; the store is on a separate, secure website.Negatives:1. Fiesta needs to address a few bugs that cause the game to crash repeatedly, usually caused by switching areas or standing around in populated areas. This is causing the existing community to slowly leave, however the most popular server (Bijou as of this writing) still enjoys a large population. If you want to play alone or just with some close friends, you can choose one of the other servers and not be bothered much by chat spammers or other annoyances.2. No Steam overlay for a Steam game.  No Steam Guard for a Steam game; it still utilizes a third-party anti-malware software (X-Trap). You can't use Steam Wallet Funds to buy Slime Coins, the currency used by the parent company, Gamigo (at least that I can find). Steam does little more than hold the shortcut for you, much like a non-Steam game you've added to your library. So what's the advantage of being a Steam game...?3. Some of the crafting skills (i.e. making potions and scrolls) require you to spend hours of real time crafting many more items than you will ever need or sell. It's something you can have the game running in the background while you do other tasks, but it is kind of a pain.4. On one hand, the game is growing: some low-level maps have had graphical updates, and the level cap has increased to 125 replete with new areas, quests, and items to find.  On the other hand, the North American servers are slowly depopulating, just because there are so many other games out there to play, and that the patches (and bugfixes!) of new content are coming too slowly. If you can find friendly players and join a Guild Academy, you are more likely to stick with playing longer. But playing solo is a real grind (even for me, and I'm used to grinding solo).Free Advice:1. You will level MUCH slower if you ignore the quests and just find a place to grind.  Until level 30 you can play as you wish, but in later levels, most of your EXP will come from completing repeated quests, not from defeating the monsters required by the quests.  That said, I hope you like grinding, because in the mid-game (say your level is in the 60s) a typical quest may require you to kill 40 of a monster for 4% of your required EXP to gain a level, and a repeatable quest will require 120 of a monster to earn 7% of the required EXP.2. Save your skill points until you have played the character for a few hours and have become comfortable with your hot-keyed skills. You cannot unspend the skill points unless you spend real money to do so. Maxing out the power and maxing out reduced cooldown time of your main attack skills is common.3. As far as your stat points, most players maximize their character's Strength in order to increase damage, unless you are a Wizard (max INT instead). Depending how you play your character, however, you may put a few points in SPR (to have some more SP and to crit more often), and perhaps a bunch in END (for extra health when you intend to get hit a lot).4. You can earn a lot of random cosmetic items by participating in month-long Attendance Events. By logging on for one hour a day per character, that character can earn a reward of 1-3 cosmetic items per week, as well as another reward for earning attendance for at least 21 of the 28-day event. Stash these items, then use them when you're bored or when you plan to do a lot of leveling!

												Summary: Fiesta is an anime-themed massively multiplayer online (MMO) game that emphasizes group play. It is simple enough for ten-year-olds, but a few annoying bugs and a very grindy lategame may discourage you after many hours of play. It is free, and buying in-game items can help speed you along without breaking the game.Positives:1. Fiesta is simple as MMOs go: you don't so much *win* the game, but you gain levels by earning EXP from completing quests. Quests mostly require killing monsters, collecting drops from monsters, or gathering items in the wilderness. The quests and overarching storyline are text-based and perhaps tangential to the game itself; there is virtually no real "roleplaying" of your character. Don't let the anime feel fool you: you spend the bulk of your active gaming time looking for monster spawn points and exterminating them.2. If dressing up your character in funny and cute cosmetic items is a draw for you, you will be pleasantly surprised at the wide variety of available costumes, hats, ears, pets, and mounts you can (rarely) earn or buy in the real-money store. Most cosmetics give a mild buff, such as increased critical hits or more EXP, and some can be earned by leveling, playing games of chance in the Lucky House, or completing timed rewards during in-game events.  You can run around in a t-shirt, butterfly wings and rainbow tube socks while fighting the bad guys, and still have all your gear equipped and active. Even a free-to-player can earn about 15 specific cosmetics by the time a character reaches level 66.3. A handful of typical classes provides some variety, but you only acquire perhaps 10-20 skills unique to each class, so there isn't the deep customization you would find in action RPGs like Diablo or World of Warcraft. That said, you can spend skill points on your favorite skills to make them more powerful, cheaper to cast, or to refresh their cooldowns faster. You also get stat points to increase the raw abilities of your character also.4. Fiesta boasts one one of the few truly female-friendly gaming communities. Also, the gender of your character can be chosen on creation regardless of class and without effect on your character's stats. Also, if you're a parent of a potential user, Fiesta has virtually no content that is inappropriate for preteens; only the chatter of the other players need be monitored. There is also no way in-game to purchase real-money content; the store is on a separate, secure website.Negatives:1. Fiesta needs to address a few bugs that cause the game to crash repeatedly, usually caused by switching areas or standing around in populated areas. This is causing the existing community to slowly leave, however the most popular server (Bijou as of this writing) still enjoys a large population. If you want to play alone or just with some close friends, you can choose one of the other servers and not be bothered much by chat spammers or other annoyances.2. No Steam overlay for a Steam game.  No Steam Guard for a Steam game; it still utilizes a third-party anti-malware software (X-Trap). You can't use Steam Wallet Funds to buy Slime Coins, the currency used by the parent company, Gamigo (at least that I can find). Steam does little more than hold the shortcut for you, much like a non-Steam game you've added to your library. So what's the advantage of being a Steam game...?3. Some of the crafting skills (i.e. making potions and scrolls) require you to spend hours of real time crafting many more items than you will ever need or sell. It's something you can have the game running in the background while you do other tasks, but it is kind of a pain.4. On one hand, the game is growing: some low-level maps have had graphical updates, and the level cap has increased to 125 replete with new areas, quests, and items to find.  On the other hand, the North American servers are slowly depopulating, just because there are so many other games out there to play, and that the patches (and bugfixes!) of new content are coming too slowly. If you can find friendly players and join a Guild Academy, you are more likely to stick with playing longer. But playing solo is a real grind (even for me, and I'm used to grinding solo).Free Advice:1. You will level MUCH slower if you ignore the quests and just find a place to grind.  Until level 30 you can play as you wish, but in later levels, most of your EXP will come from completing repeated quests, not from defeating the monsters required by the quests.  That said, I hope you like grinding, because in the mid-game (say your level is in the 60s) a typical quest may require you to kill 40 of a monster for 4% of your required EXP to gain a level, and a repeatable quest will require 120 of a monster to earn 7% of the required EXP.2. Save your skill points until you have played the character for a few hours and have become comfortable with your hot-keyed skills. You cannot unspend the skill points unless you spend real money to do so. Maxing out the power and maxing out reduced cooldown time of your main attack skills is common.3. As far as your stat points, most players maximize their character's Strength in order to increase damage, unless you are a Wizard (max INT instead). Depending how you play your character, however, you may put a few points in SPR (to have some more SP and to crit more often), and perhaps a bunch in END (for extra health when you intend to get hit a lot).4. You can earn a lot of random cosmetic items by participating in month-long Attendance Events. By logging on for one hour a day per character, that character can earn a reward of 1-3 cosmetic items per week, as well as another reward for earning attendance for at least 21 of the 28-day event. Stash these items, then use them when you're bored or when you plan to do a lot of leveling!

												I read another review here that said that this game is recommended to those who are just starting to play mmorpgs. I completely agree. Fiesta was one of the first mmorpgs I've ever played and somehow, I still love it (even with all the repetiveness and grinding). Why? The community is nice (which I find very assuring when you're just a starter, so this is the big concept I want to point out to beginners). People will always help you when you're least expecting it; whether it be a random buff from a cleric or people asking if you need help in your guild -you can always rely on the community. I might be naive saying this, but I've played other mmorpgs to some extent as well, and at some point they all have their repetiveness, so as far as the gameplay goes... what's so bad? The skills have increasing levels that you unlock as you level up, and skills that you eventually come to gain. You don't come equipped with all your skills and for me, I found that such an exciting experience when I first started playing. [If anyone else has played Vindictus then I would like to compare: you do get skills along the way, and can level them up to some degree, but unless you're not into the whole paladin/dark knight thing then there's no other skills] I always looked forward to getting new skills in Fiesta and still do (because I haven't reached the level cap yet since I've taken such a long time off this game, but I still come back to it).Now if you don't like grinding or P2W then sorry; this is definitely NOT the game for you if you plan on playing it for a while. This is the reason I've taken long breaks and the only reason.Overall, I definitely recommend this games to starters of the mmorpg worlds. Even so, I still recommend this game to experienced mmorpg players as well. This game goes back to the classics. Classes of Fighter, Mage, Cleric, and Archer can never let you down. To add, the developers have even added Trickster, and Crusader to those who want a little variety. note* Crusader becomes availible at level 60. I always seem to come back to this game even if it is repetitive because I miss it, and I think others who have reviewed have the same feelings. It's a relaxing game that has cute sprites and reliable gameplay. I think that's all from me ^^

												Game is very pay2win and grindy after you get to a certain level. Spamming repeats and saving quests for levels with no repeats is the only way to level after a while. But there's more than just spamming repeats. There are Kingdom Quests, where you join other similar leveled people to beat the boss...or survive for a period of time.  The Kingdom quests and the anime style are the two reasons I keep coming back. The population isn't very high, but there is a server merge going on, so that might fix things like people buying instance runs. The economy is also very broken. Things that used to cost like 80g now cost gems because the server is being flooded with money with no good gold sink. Even with all the problems with this game, I still recommend it. I still enjoy playing and interacting with the community in game.Edit: As much as I liked this game, even I have to admit that Fiesta is dead at this point. I've seen some things...like people being paid small amounts to just make a Fiesta account. I've moved on, and so should other people who play this game, or are thinking about playing this game.
